citation.article-title: Pseudomonas reinekei sp. nov., Pseudomonas moorei sp. nov. and Pseudomonas mohnii sp. nov., novel species capable of degrading chlorosalicylates or isopimaric acid
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Pseudomonas reinekei sp. nov.

Pseudomonas reinekei (rei′ne.ke.i. N.L. gen. n. reinekei of/from Reineke, named in honour of Walter Reineke, for his pioneering contributions to the study of the biodegradation of chlorinated aromatics).
Colonies are circular, white–yellow and mucoid on LB agar and become mucoid after 2 days of incubation.
No fluorescent pigments are produced on King's B medium.
Cells are oxidase-positive and are able to form levan, but show no hydrolysis of arginine, hydrolysis of Tween 80 or reduction of nitrate.
Lecithinase, urease and β-galactosidase reactions are negative and there is no hydrolysis of aesculin or gelatin.
Indole is not produced from tryptophan and there is no glucose fermentation.
Growth does not occur at 41 °C or in media supplemented with 5 or 7 % NaCl.

Results obtained with Biolog GN2 microplates indicate that the following substrates are utilized: l-arabinose, d-arabitol, d-galactose, α-d-glucose, methyl pyruvate, monomethyl succinate, acetic acid, cis-aconitic acid, citric acid, formic acid, d-galactonic acid lactone, d-galacturonic acid, d-gluconic acid, β-hydroxybutyric acid, α-ketoglutaric acid, dl-lactic acid, quinic acid, d-saccharic acid, succinic acid, bromosuccinic acid, l-asparagine, l-aspartic acid, l-glutamic acid, l-proline, l-pyroglutamic acid, urocanic acid, phenylethylamine and glycerol.
Weak utilization is observed of d-glucosaminic acid, α-hydroxybutyric acid, malonic acid, propionic acid, alaninamide, l-alanine, l-serine, dl-carnitine and 2-aminoethanol.
The other organic substrates included in the Biolog GN2 microplates are not utilized.

Consistent with the chemical properties of the genus, the major respiratory lipoquinone present is ubiquinone 9 (Q9) and the major phospholipids are phosphatidylglycerol, diphosphatidylglycerol and phosphatidylethanolamine.
The fatty acids present include 3-OH 10 : 0, 12 : 0, 2-OH 12 : 0, 3-OH 12 : 0, 14 : 0, 16 : 1ω7c, 16 : 1ω7t, 16 : 0, cyclo 17 : 0, 18 : 1ω9c, 18 : 1ω7c, 18 : 0 and cyclo 19 : 0.
The level of 14 : 0 does not exceed 1.5 %.
The 3-OH 10 : 0 and 2-OH 12 : 0 are ester-linked, while the 3-OH 12 : 0 is amide-linked.
